Feature article A critical perspective on the design and development of metal oxide catalysts for selective propylene ammoxidation and oxidation James F. Brazdil ⁎ Archer Daniels Midland Company, Decatur, IL, 62521, USA Archer Daniels Midland Company Decatur IL 62521 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The objective of this article is to use the example of the development of metal oxide catalysts for the selective ammoxidation and oxidation of propylene to illustrate successful catalyst design strategies for achieving enhanced yields of acrylonitrile and acrolein, respectively. The processes of catalytic selective ammoxidation and oxidation of propylene are not the only, albeit they are among the most industrially significant, examples of the commercial application of metal oxide selective oxidation catalysts. Other important commercial catalytic processes that use highly developed metal oxide catalysts systems include butane oxidation to maleic anhydride and alkyl aromatic ammoxidation of toluene, xylenes, and picolines (alkyl pyridines) to produce valuable aromatic nitriles including nicotinonitrile which is the precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) an important B-complex vitamin. Using the example of industrial propylene selective (amm)oxidation, this article surveys the available patents, scientific and technical journals to chronical and analyze the development and advancement of the complex metal oxides from discovery to current state-of-the-art. Recognizing that commercial practices are proprietary, this analysis uses no known company sensitive or confidential information is included in these descriptions. From this analysis a comprehensive catalyst design strategy unfolds that is based on the enabling science of solid state chemistry and the results of the characterization tools it provides. This provides a viable platform to unlock the next level of metal oxide catalyst development with ultra-high selectivity for hydrocarbon oxidation. Keywords Metal oxide catalysts Selective oxidation Selective ammoxidation Acrylonitrile Acrolein Acrylic acid Commercial application Industrial application 1 Introduction The importance and ubiquity of metal oxides in commercial production of chemicals and chemical intermediates have their origins in some of the earliest and still important industrial processes [1–3]. Metal oxides came to the fore in catalysis with the first use of silica and alumina clays in catalytic cracking and processing of crude oil [4]. Selective oxidation, in many respects, is the quintessential application of the chemical properties of metal oxides for catalysis since it integrates the fundamental chemical nature of a metal oxide, that of being a well-defined chemical entity containing oxygen, directly into the chemical transformation. It does this by utilizing its structural oxygen atoms as the reagents in the formation of oxygen-containing hydrocarbons [5]. This remarkable characteristic of metal oxides has spawned a major segment of chemical catalysis – the upgrading of hydrocarbons to oxygen and nitrile functionalized chemical intermediates. This article will describe the development of catalysts for propylene ammoxidation and oxidation wherein the chemical and structural features that characterize metal oxides are clearly evident, fully employed and readily exemplified for the reader. The intent of this article is to provide an industrial perspective from both patent and scientific literature. From this analysis a catalyst design strategy is proposed based on the enabling science of solid state chemistry and the results of the characterization tools it provides. 2 Ammoxidation of propylene The manufacture of acrylonitrile by the selective oxidation of propylene with ammonia (generally referred to as selective ammoxidation) represents one of the largest and commercially important applications of metal oxides catalysts. Worldwide capacity for acrylonitrile production is currently around 7 million metric tons per year (7mte/yr). The first report of the catalyzed reaction of propylene and ammonia was in 1949 in a patent assigned to Allied Chemical [6]. The catalyst used was a mixed oxide of V-Mo-P-O which produced less than a 10% yield of acrylonitrile. Because of the low yield, this catalyst was never commercialized for acrylonitrile production. A viable commercial propylene ammoxidation process awaited the discovery and subsequent patenting in 1959 [7] of a process using as a catalyst the mixed metal oxide Bi9PMo12O52 supported on 50wt% SiO2by researchers at The Standard Oil Co. (Ohio) (also called SOHIO). This relatively simple mixture of metal oxides provided a yield of up to 70% and was sufficient for the first commercial plant in 1960 [8]. The one step conversion of propylene to acrylonitrile was also patented by The Distillers Co using the mixed oxides of Sn-Sb-O [9,10]. This first generation catalyst consisting of mixed oxides of tin and antimony gave generally lower acrylonitrile yields than the 70% obtained with the first generation of bismuth molybdate [11]. Both catalyst types were commercialized in the first industrial acrylonitrile production plants using propylene as the feedstock as shown in Fig. 1 . This propylene-based process quickly displaced all the existing commercial acrylonitrile production which was at the time based on acetylene, a much more expensive feedstock than propylene. Subsequently the performance differential between these two families of oxide catalysts has been sustained through the multiple generations of improved catalysts built on each basic oxide catalyst platform. This is the reason the bismuth molybdate family of catalysts became, and is still today, the dominant catalyst system in use commercially for the manufacture of acrylonitrile. This commercial dominance of the bismuth molybdate catalyst system is primarily a direct result of its chemical versatility and demonstrated capability to enhance the acrylonitrile yield and selectivity through a myriad of both structural and compositional modifications of the catalytically active bismuth molybdate phase. Bismuth molybdate exists crystallographically as one of three phases commonly denoted as α-Bi2Mo3O12, β-Bi2Mo2O9, and γ-Bi2MoO6. The structures of the α-, β-, and γ-bismuth molybdates are well understood structurally from X-ray and neutron diffraction analyses [12–14]. The catalyst is typically prepared by a co-precipitation procedure using aqueous solutions of bismuth nitrate and ammonium molybdate [15]. The catalyst is produced by drying the precipitate and heat treating the dried particles to crystallize the bismuth molybdate phase. Heat treatment temperature for bismuth molybdate catalysts is generally around 500°C. In addition to the catalyst, another important aspect of this technology is the use of the catalyst in a fluid-bed rather than the more widely used fixed-bed reactor. In order to function successfully in the abrasive environment of a fluid-bed reactor, the bismuth molybdate catalyst is supported on silica to provide hardness and attrition resistance. Both the physical properties and the content of the silica support affect the attrition resistance (i.e. harness) of a supported metal oxide catalyst. Fig. 2 illustrates these effects with data from the patent literature. The chart shows that the attrition resistance of a supported propylene ammoxidation improves (i.e. less catalyst losses) as the particle size of the silica support decreases from 86nm to 8nm. Further the chart insert shows, as one would expect, that the amount of silica support also affects attrition resistance with the higher level of silica support providing the harder catalyst. The first advancement in the development of advanced multicomponent bismuth molybdate propylene ammoxidation catalysts was taken by Knapsack-Griesheim Aktiengesellschaft [16,17]. This was the incorporation of iron into the original bismuth phosphomolybdate catalyst of SOHIO. The result was a marked enhancement in catalytic activity and productivity, that is, the ability to produce a greater amount of oxidation or ammoxidation product per amount of catalyst than could be produced with the original Bi-P-Mo-O propylene ammoxidation catalyst. This higher productivity evinces the fact that the iron increases the specific activity of bismuth molybdate catalysts. Such an increase in specific activity is understood to stem from the redox activity of iron which in turn results in an increase in the turnover number of the catalytically active sites. Higher productivity with the iron-promoted catalyst is also a result of the increase in surface area (and a resulting increase in the number of catalytically active sites) of the catalyst. A further advance in this oxidation/ammoxidation catalyst technology was the introduction of cobalt and nickel which form divalent molybdates having the formulas CoMoO4 and NiMoO4. This compositional modification was first disclosed by Nippon Kayaku Co. for use as a catalyst for the selective oxidation of propylene to acrolein [18]. In combination with the mixed metal oxide Fe-Bi-Mo-O, the divalent cobalt and nickel molybdates resulted in a significant enhancement of activity, selectivity and yield. This discovery was applied to the propylene ammoxidation process by SOHIO and subsequently further improved by the additional of an alkali metal promoter additive, in particular potassium, producing a complex mixed metal oxide consisting of M+ (e.g. K)-M2+(e.g. Co and Ni)-Fe-Bi-Mo-O [19]. This progression in the formulation of commercial propylene ammoxidation catalysts has been graphically illustrated in the literature (Fig. 3 ) in relation to the concomitant improvements in acrylonitrile yield and the growth of industrial production [20]. Solid state characterization of these multi-metal catalyst systems soon revealed that the added metal compositions exist in the catalyst as a mixture of metal molybdates [21]. These molybdates exist as separate and distinct phases. One example of the evidence for redox promotion by the addition of iron was the observed increase in electrical conductivity as a function of iron content in a cobalt iron molybdate solid solution [22]. These phases are chemically described as: • Divalent M2+MoO4 molybdates of the α and/or β structure type in which M2+ one or more of Ni2+, Co2+, Mg2+, Fe2+ typically as a single solid solution • Trivalent Fe2Mo3O12 • Bismuth molybdate invariably as the α-Bi2Mo3O12 structure type. It was thus apparent that the promoter effect of these additional molybdate phases of nickel/cobalt and iron to the active bismuth molybdate phase must entail a synergistic chemical interaction between these phases in order to effect the observed increased product yields. This synergy between crystallographically distinct phases has been articulated in various ways in the literature but is still not well understood chemically. Unfortunately so far, direct in-situ evidence for the proposed models is lacking. Three models have been proposed for multiphasic metal oxide catalyst to explain this synergistic affect and go by the following general descriptors: 1. “support effects” 2. “remote control mechanism” 3. “interfacial effect” or “structural epitaxy” The “support effect” model envisions the catalytically active phase (in this case bismuth molybdate) supported on second phase (cobalt molybdate or cobalt-iron molybdate), the later transporting its lattice oxygen to the bismuth molybdate phase under the conditions of selective propylene oxidation to acrolein [23]. This concept can be viewed in principle as an extension of that universally employed with supported metals where the spreading of one phase (i.e. catalytically active metal) over a second phase (metal oxide support) due to a chemical wetting facilitates the physical interaction, and thus the chemical/catalytic interaction of the two phases. This model has been applied to the mixed metal oxide bismuth-iron-cobalt-molybdate selective oxidation catalyst system described above. In this case the promoting cobalt molybdate phase serves effectively as a support for the catalytically active bismuth molybdate phase. The postulate of a “strong interaction” between the two phases serves as the conduit for transfer of lattice oxygen during the catalytic cycle. The “remote control” model envisions the co-existence of two metal oxides in physical contact in a multiphase catalyst. One of the oxides serves as a so-called donor while the other is the so-called acceptor. The critical feature of the donor is the ability to dissociate O2 to create mobile surface oxygen species that then migrate, or “spill over”, to the acceptor phase, The donor phase is generally the catalytically active phase (bismuth molybdate in the case of propylene oxidation) having the surface active sites for selective oxidation. This model has been applied to a wide range of multiphase metal oxides including molybdenum, antimony and vanadium oxide based [24–26]. Finally, the approach of “interfacial interactions” or “epitaxy” is based on fundamental principles of solid state chemistry that describe how two or more crystallographically distinct solid materials form chemically and structurally interacting phase boundaries (i.e. coherent interfaces). It has been applied to several cases of multiphasic metal oxide selective oxidation catalysis to good effect. The concept has been well described and explained in several articles by Courtine and by Bordes [27–30]. The key requirement underpinning the functioning of all three models is the fact that when strong synergistic effects are observed, a high degree of phase contact is noted [31]. Nevertheless, the most striking gap in data needed to select among these models for this synergistic effect is any direct physical observation of the phenomenon either during or after a multiphase catalyst is exposed to reaction conditions. The metal oxides most frequently studied have relatively low Tamm temperatures and will thus undergo potentially significant solid state changes under the high temperature redox conditions of reaction. These changes are likely to have a direct bearing on the physical form the contact between the interacting phases and thus need to be taken into account. In-situ or post reaction solid state characterization of multiphasic selective oxidation and ammoxidation catalysts is a clear need in this important and commercially relevant area of catalysis science. These three models for multiphase synergy in catalysis are not in actuality mutually exclusive. In fact, they are all describing the phenomena in somewhat different terms but with the same physical perspective. That said, among these models it is the latter one employing structural epitaxy that has the advantage of the ability to be applied and tested in a predictive way. This is in sharp contrast to the other conceptual models which generally can only be applied in principle to explain empirical evidence of synergy after the fact. The epitaxy model is grounded in sound understandings of thermodynamic and structural properties of solids. This makes the approach of interfacial contact and epitaxy an attractive, robust and potentially powerful tool for catalyst design and improvement. The application of the solid state structural phenomenon of epitaxy has the potential for wide application across a broad spectrum of materials that serve as heterogeneous catalysts. Although the model can be criticized as inapplicable to explaining the surface phenomenon of catalysis, it is important to note that in the case of selective oxidation, particularly involving the Mars-van Krevelen redox mechanism, that a significant and critical contribution from the bulk of the metal oxide is required. It is through the bulk that the lattice oxygen reagent for the reaction must migrate from the sight of gaseous oxygen reduction to the site of oxygen insertion. In turn, the bulk solid must be able to transfer electrons from the active site to the site of oxygen activation employing the redox functionality of the lattice constituents. In addition, as noted by P. Courtine on this subject “…the nature of the active site, which can contain a normal lattice ion, a group of ions, or extended or point defects, depends on its solid state environment. The structure of the host matrix can greatly influence the chemical and physical properties of the site.” And “it was found in certain cases that the surface structures bear some relations with the bulk structure” [28]. In principle the epitaxy model can be applied to any multiphasic catalytic system wherein structural coherency between specific crystal planes of the interacting phases occurs and where disregistry between the contacting planes is minimized and thus creating a pseudo-single phase local environment [32,33]. In this environment, electron and oxygen ion transfer can occur or be promoted by a specific chemical phase or multiple phases and thereby provide enhancement to the redox function of selective oxidation catalysis. Redox functionality is critical to both activity and selectivity for metal oxide selective oxidation catalysts [34]. This catalyst design strategy, however, is limited in its ability to provide for higher yield catalysts largely because of the natural paucity of molybdate-based crystal structures likely to be able to achieve ideal epitaxial coherence. Conceptually, the ideal case of coherence and compositional homogeneity only truly occurs within a single crystal phase in the form of solid solutions. This situation is achieved by incorporating as many of the key functionalities of the selective oxidation mechanism into a single crystal structure. Ideally this can be accomplished by the formation of solid solutions of the elemental constituents that exhibit the requisite catalytic functions (i.e. α-hydrogen abstraction from propylene and redox activity) into a single phase molybdate structure. This fundamental understanding serves as the basis for the catalyst design strategy for the next improved generation of selective ammoxidation catalysts [35]. Application of the advanced catalyst design principles described above have helped lead to the development of high-performing state of the art complex metal oxide catalysts for acrylonitrile production from propylene. The genesis of this stage of catalyst design was to focus research first on the understanding of, and then the chemical manipulation of, the key catalytically active phase of the most widely used catalyst, namely Bi2Mo3O12. This focus entailed analysis of the key solid state structural aspects of the parent defect scheelite structure of the Bi2Mo3O12 phase which is based on the ideal CaWO4 crystal structure [36,37]. The earliest work on this single phase catalyst design strategy centered on understanding the defect structure of scheelite (Bi2/3▯1/3Mo3O12 where ▯ represents a cation vacancy in the ideal ABO4 structure [38]) and further to the manipulation of the defect content of the scheelite phase [39,40]. The results of these early studies are graphically summarized in Fig. 4 [41]. The results reveal that both bismuth and cation vacancy concentrations affect activity for conversion of propylene to acrylonitrile. The most critical result is the observation that in the absence of bismuth, defect cation vacancies serve no catalytic function in isolation and do not effect activation of propylene to form the requisite allylic intermediate [42–44]. As shown in Fig. 4, catalytic behavior of the bismuth-free single phase scheelite solid solution Pb2+ 1−3xLa3+ 2x▯xMoO4 has low catalytic activity and exhibits no discernible activity or selectivity trend with the concentration of cation vacancies present. Instead the formation of acrylonitrile is proportional to the amount of bismuth present and confirms that bismuth is a necessary constituent of the active site responsible for the rate determining α-hydrogen abstraction step, either directly or indirectly. Incorporation of catalytically functional elemental components as a solid solution with the catalytically active scheelite bismuth molybdate phase was first demonstrated with iron [45,46]. An iron-containing scheelite bismuth molybdate was synthesized having the formulation Bi3FeMo2O12. The iron substitution within the defect scheelite structure is unconventional for the generic defect scheelite A2/3▯1/3MoO4 in that iron substitutes for a molybdenum because of the less than 10% difference in ionic radii for Fe3+ and Mo6+ (0.645Å and 0.59Å, respectively [47]) while Bi3+ occupies the normally vacant large A cation site. The resulting multi-metal molybdate can be described in terms of the normal scheelite formulation as (Bi2/3Bi1/3)(Fe1/3Mo2/3)O4 thus removing any cation vacancy defect character in the scheelite structure. This bismuth-iron-molybdate phase was found to exist in two polymorphic forms. One form has iron and molybdenum ordered on the B sites of the ABO4 scheelite thus providing a monoclinic structure type with a superstructure formed by three scheelite subcells. The other form has iron and molybdenum randomly occupying the B sites and thus giving the standard higher symmetry tetragonal structure of normal ABO4 scheelite. The benefit of a strategy of combining a redox active element with bismuth molybdate in a single phase is evident from the observed three-fold enhancement in the rate of oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-butene to butadiene when iron is present. Subsequently, the presence of this phase was shown to provide significant yield improvements in a complex mixed metal oxide catalyst for the selective oxidation and ammoxidation of an alcohol and/or alkene for the production of unsaturated nitriles, aldehydes or olefins including the production of acrylonitrile by propylene ammoxidation [48]. The original work on synthesis and characterization of the Bi3FeMo2O12 phase provided the first evidence that close integration of a redox active multivalent element (i.e. Fe2+ ↔Fe3+) with the catalytically active bismuth and molybdenum oxide active site can achieve significant enhancements in catalytic behavior in a selective oxidation reaction. The subsequent advancement in mixed metal oxide selective oxidation catalyst development was the successful integration of the two most impactful solid state structural design concepts described above – 1. synergistic phases interaction (most effectively via structural epitaxy) and 2. solid solution/single phase formation within the catalytically active phase. This dual catalyst design strategy is exemplified with the mixed metal bismuth-cerium-molybdate catalyst system. Cerium doping of a bismuth molybdate oxidation catalyst was first reported in the 1980’s with the disclosure of the “Bi9CeMo12O52” composition as an effective catalyst for propylene ammoxidation [49]. Subsequently, cerium has been disclosed in numerous patents as a constituent of complex multicomponent catalysts for commercial application [50–54]. These newest commercial catalyst formulations were built upon, and explained by, the earlier fundamental characterization studies of the bismuth-cerium-molybdate mixed oxide system [55,56]. It was from this seminal work that it was discovered that the bismuth molybdate scheelite structure is able to accommodate a redox active element other than iron, namely cerium, but by a different mechanism compared to iron. By examining a broad composition range covering the entire defect scheelite stoichiometry for the series BixCe2−x▯Mo3O12 with 0≤x≤2 it was possible to construct a phase diagram for this mixed metal oxide system that revealed two solid solutions spanning this composition range. This was based on earlier structural characterization of the pure end member molybdate phases of the series [57]. One solid solution consists of cerium dissolved in the α-Bi2Mo3O12 structure for x greater than about 1.8. The second solid solution consists of bismuth dissolved in the cerium molybdate structure when x is less than about one. Enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity is effected by enabling the Ce3+ ↔Ce4+ redox couple at the atomic level in the direct vicinity of catalytically essential component bismuth and molybdenum necessary for the activation of propylene via α-H abstraction and subsequent oxygen/nitrogen insertion. The role of a redox couple in selective oxidation catalysis has been shown, as discussed above, to facilitate lattice oxygen migration from the bulk to the surface active site. However, in contrast to previous catalyst designs in which the solid solution of FexCo1−xMoO4 coexists as a separate phase along with α-Bi2Mo3O12 to promote this oxygen transfer mechanism, in the BixCe2−x▯Mo3O12 solid solution series, the redox active promoter, cerium, effects this redox promotion directly within the same structural phase as catalytically active components bismuth and molybdenum. From the perspective of efficacy and simplicity, the concept of having a single phase encompassing the three critical catalytic function, activation, insertion and redox, is clearly advantageous. In the solid solution the distance between the catalytically active elements (bismuth and molybdenum) and the multivalent redox active promoters (cerium and iron) is on the atomic scale. This is in contrast to having the catalytically active element(s) and the redox promoter(s) in separate crystalline phases where the distance between the two components in on the order of the crystallite size – 100–1000Å. The former provides the most direct, and thus the more efficient, interaction between these two critical components of the working catalyst. This creates a highly effective catalytic site for selective activation and oxidative transformation of propylene than a site having only bismuth as occurs with α-Bi2Mo3O12. Further work on this bismuth-cerium molybdate system has shown the solid solution phase to be more complex than a simple homogeneous distribution of the bismuth and cerium cations in the defect scheelite structure [58]. Evidence points to a subtle random preference of bismuth and cerium for specific crystallographic sites in the structure. This unconventional distribution of catalytically active cations in a molybdate oxide structure provides for the intriguing option of atomic level manipulation of atom coordination in oxide catalysts analogous to molecular level design of discrete homogenous catalyst moieties such as metallocenes and even akin to modification of enzyme catalysts or DNA in biological systems. In the context of metal oxide based catalysts, atomic level manipulation means the ability to situate a specific element, existing in one or more specific oxidation states, into a specific site in a crystal lattice in order to deliver optimum functionality for the catalyzed transformation i.e. chemisorption of reagents, activation of hydrocarbon by hydrogen abstraction, oxygen or nitrogen insertion, O2 reduction and electron and lattice oxygen transport between surface and bulk and between catalytic surface sites (active site and lattice reoxidation). In the two phase region of the BixCe2−x▯Mo3O12 the phenomenon of phase synergy is also exemplified as shown in Fig. 5 . A maximum in catalytic activity for the selective ammoxidation of propylene to acrylonitrile is observed at the compositions corresponding to the phase boundaries where the solubility limits of cerium in bismuth molybdate and bismuth in cerium molybdate occur. These specific compositions maximize the number of neighboring bismuth and cerium cations in a single phase structure. Also the maximum in catalytic activity that is observed for the multiphase region of the phase diagram necessarily arises from interactions between the separate phases. Thermodynamic and structural analyses show that the bismuth rich and cerium rich solid solutions are likely to form coherent interfaces at the phase boundaries due to the structural similarities between the two phases which can permit epitaxial nucleation and growth. A good lattice match exists between the (010) faces of the compounds [59,60]. This is apparent from the summary of the calculated misfits between crystal planes of the two solid solutions shown in Table 1 . The low misfit and disregistry along the (010) crystal faces of the two solid solutions are strongly indicative of the likely formation of a structurally coherent interface. In an effort to add a thermodynamic basis for catalytic synergy between coexisting phases, it is possible to state the occurrence of coherent interface as a minimization of the excess free energy of forming the interface. This excess free energy is the difference between the free energy of forming separate phases and the free energy of forming the interface [61,62]. In the case of the coexistence of the two solid solutions, this excess free energy is directly related to the local free energy at the interface which reduces to the following free energy function: Δf =RT[XAln(aA/aA e)+XBln(aB/ab e) where X is the mole fraction of each component, a and ae are the activities of the component at the interface and in the equilibrium solid solution, respectively and R is the gas constant and T is temperature treatment for formation of the phases prior to quenching to room temperature. Thus, it is expected that at a specific composition in the multiphase region where this fee energy function is minimized, the structural similarity of the phases is conducive to coherent phase boundary formation, and the maximum number of possible interfacial contacts occurs will be the optimum composition to achieve catalytic synergy. [63]. This point will obviously be different for each multiphase system but in principle it could be both calculable and empirically identified. This concept of structurally coherent phase boundaries applies to the other known multicomponent mixed-phase oxide catalyst system including those described herein. As exemplified in the case of bismuth-cerium molybdates, close structural similarity between the two saturated solid solutions permits mutual epitaxial growth which produces a local chemical environment akin to that of a single phase catalyst. As a consequence, oxygen ion and electron transfer between the individual phases will be facilitated when the compositional non-uniformity of the region at the interface is minimized. Thus, the existence of coherent phase boundaries between the separate catalytically active phases is a key reason for maximum catalytic activity in this, and other, multicomponent catalyst. From the standpoint of the state-of-the-art for industrial application of multicomponent mixed metal oxide catalysts for selective oxidation and ammoxidation, the most recently disclosed formulations [64–68] are built upon cerium incorporation into bismuth containing mixed metal molybdate phases – most importantly the bismuth cerium molybdate scheelite phase. These complex catalyst systems conceptually take advantage of the above described chemistry extant with the catalytically active bismuth cerium molybdate solutions. However, in the case of the commercial catalyst formulations, there are additional complex solid state phase interactions due to the separate molybdate compounds created by the iron, nickel, cobalt, magnesium promoter additives as described above [69]. 3 Oxidation of propylene In commercial practice, the catalytic selective oxidation of propylene over mixed metal oxide catalysts is the first of a two-step oxidation process to produce acrylic acid. In this first step propylene is selectively oxidized to primarily acrolein (>80%) along with acrylic acid(∼8–10%). The overall yield of acrolein plus acrylic acid is typically higher than the yield of acrylonitrile from propylene ammoxidation over the same or similar catalysts. Essentially the same the mechanistic and catalyst design fundamentals described above for propylene ammoxidation to acrylonitrile also apply to propylene oxidation to acrolein and both reactions have been used in parallel in most reaction kinetic, mechanistic and computational modeling studies [70,71]. A key question for a commercial catalytic process, and one that is rarely addressed, is what is the theoretical yield limit? The answer to this question is manifestly important for an industrial process as it would direct any research and development efforts to areas of the process technology that the maximize benefit relative to cost of the effort. Improvement in catalyst yields, though implicitly usually the goal of research studies may not be the most prudent approach. The catalyzed selective oxidation of propylene is one process that has been examined using computational kinetic modeling to try and ascertain the so-call yield bound for the process [72]. The approach was to apply an optimization algorithm to adjust 23 nonlinear model parameters using a 57 elementary-step kinetic mechanism for propylene oxidation to acrolein. In the first step of the two-step process, where propylene is converted into acrolein, a predicted yield of 96.41% is obtained from the optimization, compared to the highest experimental yield of 90% reported in the literature. This indicates that there is substantial opportunity for improvement of this step by catalyst design and development. As shown in Fig. 6 , where acrolein selectivity versus propylene conversion curves were plotted using the optimized parameter values, the selectivity of acrolein in the first step could be very close to 100%. However, when propylene conversion reached around 98%, both acrolein selectivity and yields dropped dramatically. The formation of CO2 accounts for the reduced acrolein yields and selectivity in the high propylene conversion region in Fig. 6. In the second step of the two-step of acrolein oxidation, the optimized yield of acrylic acid was 97.87%. This is similar to the highest yield of 97% reported experimentally which indicates that the existing catalysts for this step are quite close to the limit of what is achievable. The selectivity and yields of acrylic acid as a function of acrolein conversion using the optimized parameter values are also shown in Fig. 6. It was found that even for the optimized case of acrolein oxidation, the yields of CO2 were found to be around 2%. Thus, the formation of some CO2 appears to be unavoidable in this step. 4 Conclusions, perspectives and future directions The primary tools used to develop and understand these important metal oxide materials are largely those of the enabling science of solid state chemistry. It is this tool of science that has provided the best and most successful strategy for manipulating the chemistry of these complex oxide systems. A solid state chemistry based catalyst design strategy remains a proven means by which it is possible to continue to discover, develop and improve heterogeneous catalysts for commercial use. Advanced structural analyses that probe the very atomic level characteristics of metal oxides have been found to directly correlate to catalytic behavior and mechanism. Among the solid state characterizations of metal oxides that have proven valuable for both fundamental understanding and for new catalyst development include quantitative phase composition, point and extended defect structures, atomic composition and structure of crystalline, the presence and nature of microcrystalline and amorphous phases, crystallite size, bulk and surface composition and structure, kinetics and thermodynamics of phase formation and transformation, phase boundary and intergrowth structures, and crystal site occupancy. Especially impactful would be obtaining atomic level resolution of interfaces in multiphasic oxide selective oxidation catalyst system by the application of the solid state characterization tools of, for example, high resolution electron microscopy and atomic force microcopy. The goal would be to find, for example, direct evidence for example, coherent interfaces as giving rise to synergistic effects in a catalyzed selective oxidation reaction. Although the catalytic process for acrylonitrile production described in this article are considered mature because they were originally commercialized in 1960, the catalysts that are employed commercially in this process and related commercial catalytic processes are by no means mature or at the apex of their theoretical performance potential. Thus, future developments will look to finding the chemical means to unlock high selectivity in these processes. The platform of metal oxide chemistry remains a highly tenable vehicle to achieve this. An area in particular that warrants future study is the solid state dynamics occurring both during synthesis and under reaction conditions. The solid state properties discussed here all are a function of temperature and gas phase environment. In many cases this property is used to advantage to synthesize the best performing structure of the metal oxide and maintain its catalytic behavior under reaction conditions. However, the as-synthesized state of the metal oxide generally further transforms under the dynamics of the catalytic reaction induced by the high temperature of reaction and, in the case of selective oxidation, by the movement of lattice oxygens within the bulk and surface of the metal oxide. Such dynamic processes can alter the optimum composition and structure of a selective active site and result in a site structure and metal occupancy of that site that is non-selective for the reaction and produce COx. The design of structures and elemental constituents that stabilize the active site composition and the local atomic coordination that catalyze only the selective oxidative transformation of the reactant and reaction intermediates yield is an obvious remit of the capabilities solid state chemistry. The potential for the local atomic coordination of a cation in an oxide structure (notably molybdenum in the scheelite Bi2Mo3O12 structure) to affect catalytic functionality has also been postulated based on molecular modeling studies [73]. Multifunctionality is the hallmark of selective oxidation by metal oxide catalysts. In turn, it is the ability of metal oxides and their myriad of structure types that are able to form solid solutions having multiple metals coexist in common spatial arrangement as well as their ability to create interacting phase boundaries that enables the potential for catalyst design on an atomic scale. By analogy, this is closely akin to the science of DNA modification in biological systems. So in conclusion in the case of heterogeneous catalysis, it is the atomic level, nano-scale, manipulation of the elemental composition and structure of a catalytically active metal oxide phase that will likely ultimately realize the vision of ultra-high selectivity in hydrocarbon oxidation catalysis. 5 Broader application of metal oxide design principles for 21st century technology development Advancement in catalytic technologies typically proceed along two fronts – feedstock replacement and catalyst replacement – in an effort to provide lower production costs or to achieve other strategic, technical, economic or societal objectives. Taking commercial acrylonitrile manufacture as the example, feedstock replacement has been an active focus area for research for several decades. Replacement of propylene with inherently lower cost propane has clearly led to many creative new process and catalyst developments. These developments have even resulted in the construction of one acrylonitrile production plant using propane feedstock. Despite this important achievement, it is also clear that for further commercial penetration of a propane-based acrylonitrile process it will still require significant catalyst yield improvement in excess of the current 60% before displacement of the existing propylene-based process can be considered an eventuality. Specifically, the best acrylonitrile yields for the apparent catalyst formulation used commercially [74] – Mo1V0.206Nb0.10 Sb0.22 W0.03 Ce0.005+47wt% SiO2–which incorporates the many preparative and calcination protocols necessary to achieve the optimum non-equilibrium physical and structural state of this mixed oxide, are at the original reported values in the 1990s of 56–58% acrylonitrile yield [75]. Similarly, biomass-derived glycerol has also been proposed as a feedstock source for acrylonitrile manufacture [76]. Here too, the present state of the catalyst and process technologies are likely not yet such to economically justify commercial displacement of the existing propylene-based process. In fact, the projected economic and societal incentives for a glycerol-based acrylonitrile production process are still debatable [77,78]. With respect to future advances in metal oxide catalysts, it is worth envisioning how and where the solid state chemistry principles described above for selective oxidation catalyst have broader impact for emerging technologies of current interest other than catalysis. One that can be used for illustrative purposes is the design of new materials for new energy applications. It has been reported [79] that the most efficient materials to date for thermoelectric generation of electricity from the waste heat was achieved with terbium (a redox active rare earth element) doping of a calcium cobalt oxide having cobalt in an atypical oxidation state greater than 2+. The result is a redox active defect solid solution. The new material can be represented as Ca3-xTbxCo4O9 where the single phase solid solution exists for 0<x≤0.5. Electrical neutrality in the solid solution is maintained by the multivalent capabilities of both terbium and cobalt. It is also likely that cation vacancies or other defects are generated in the structure by the variability of the oxidation states of terbium and cobalt in the structure. The composition at x=0.5–the solubility maximum in the solid solution – is the point where optimal thermoelectric properties and carrier transport are achieved. It is not difficult to see that these are the same solid state structural design concepts described herein that have been used successfully for the design and development of the most technically advanced redox active metal oxide catalysts for selective propylene ammoxidation and oxidation. Summary: James Brazdil is director of catalysis research at Archer Daniels Midland Company with extensive previous experience in the chemical industry in the areas of catalyst development and commercialization, catalyst manufacture, chemical process development, fundamental catalysis research, spectroscopy, solid state chemistry, and inorganic synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The objective of this article is to use the example of the development of metal oxide catalysts for the selective ammoxidation and oxidation of propylene to illustrate successful catalyst design strategies for achieving enhanced yields of acrylonitrile and acrolein, respectively. The processes of catalytic selective ammoxidation and oxidation of propylene are not the only, albeit they are among the most industrially significant, examples of the commercial application of metal oxide selective oxidation catalysts. Other important commercial catalytic processes that use highly developed metal oxide catalysts systems include butane oxidation to maleic anhydride and alkyl aromatic ammoxidation of toluene, xylenes, and picolines (alkyl pyridines) to produce valuable aromatic nitriles including nicotinonitrile which is the precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) an important B-complex vitamin. Using the example of industrial propylene selective (amm)oxidation, this article surveys the available patents, scientific and technical journals to chronical and analyze the development and advancement of the complex metal oxides from discovery to current state-of-the-art. Recognizing that commercial practices are proprietary, this analysis uses no known company sensitive or confidential information is included in these descriptions. From this analysis a comprehensive catalyst design strategy unfolds that is based on the enabling science of solid state chemistry and the results of the characterization tools it provides. This provides a viable platform to unlock the next level of metal oxide catalyst development with ultra-high selectivity for hydrocarbon oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: A critical perspective on the design and development of metal oxide catalysts for selective propylene ammoxidation and oxidation
